title: Must every essay have a title? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, technically every essay should be titled, even if you wish to title it “Untitled.” However, the title of an essay is meant to allude to the subject and grab the reader’s attention; an untitled (or “Untitled”) essay does not serve this purpose. Get creative and grab ahold of someone who normally would not pick up and read a random essay. Writing an essay about Shakespeare’s Hamlet? Don’t title it “Hamlet.” Instead, pick some interesting things that you touch upon in the essay. “Unrequited: A Look at Love in Hamlet” or “To Kill or Not to Kill: Hamlet’s Inaction” (a play upon recognizable words from the work will usually score). The title doesn’t need to be elaborate (in fact, a title too long or indecipherable will always force a reader away). But, it must be interesting. Finally, if an academic essay, the subject should almost always be in the title. An essay on algae as biofuel? “Green Gasoline” won’t fulfill a professor’s expectations. Instead, something like “Eco-friendly: Algal Biofuels and Scum Farming” will steer the audience toward the topic nicely.

It's not mandatory for an essay to have a title, but it might be required by a specific teacher. Not only that, but titles are great and an easy way to make teachers happier, thereby increasing your mark. Titles not only tell the reader what your essay is about, but they show your teacher that you have reflected on your writing. I personally recommend titles on all things students write because it is more likely to appeal to your reader, and will likely improve your marks as well as your own understanding of what you wrote.

Any piece of writing should have a title. It isn't required, but it's very useful later on. If you simply say title a book, My Book, no one is going to look at it, much less buy it. A title, gives your readers a bit of information without reading it.

Theoretically, what you write can be whatever you want, but titles serve as the main entry point for most readers. They grab attention, establish topic and tone, or pose a question/answer, among other things. If you’re having trouble coming up with one, make it the last thing you do before you declare the piece complete.
